[[Capricorn Records|Capricorn]] | associated_acts = }} '''Johnny Darrell''' (July 23, 1940{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=106/7}} – October 7, 1997) was an American country music artist. Darrell was born in [[Hopewell, Cleburne County, Alabama|Hopewell, Alabama]] but grew up in [[Marietta, Georgia]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/johnny-darrell-mn0000202599/biography|title=Johnny Darrell | Biography & History|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=August 6, 2021}} After a stint in the army, he moved to Nashville and began managing a [[Holiday Inn]] near [[Music Row]], when he was discovered by Kelso Herstin, a producer working for United Artists, on the recommendation of [[Bobby Bare]]. In his recording career, Darrell established a trend of introducing "lyrically adventurous" songs that later became major hits for other artists. His first single, a version of [[Curly Putman]]'s "[[Green Green Grass of Home]]" was issued in 1965, followed by "As Long as the Wind Blows" in 1966, which made the country Top 30 and saw Darrell being named "Most Promising Male Artist" by [[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/obituary-johnny-darrell-1294178.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220614/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/obituary-johnny-darrell-1294178.html |archive-date=June 14, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Obituary: Johnny Darrell|newspaper=[[The Independent]] |first=Paul| last=Wadey|access-date=June 13, 2020|date=November 15, 1997 }} He was the first to record the [[Mel Tillis]] song "[[Ruby, Don't Take Your Love to Town]]", which became a top ten hit for him in 1967 and later a hit for [[Kenny Rogers]]. This was followed by his performance of [[Dallas Frazier]]'s "[[The Son of Hickory Holler's Tramp]]" in 1968, and the crossover hit "[[With Pen in Hand]]", which would later become a hit for [[Vikki Carr]]. In the 1970s, Darrell was associated with the [[Outlaw country]] movement. Darrell suffered from [[diabetes]], a disease which would impair his health and ability to perform. Darrell died from the disease at age 57 in [[Kennesaw, Georgia]], and was survived by his wife Jody.{{Cite web|url=http://www.alamhof.org/darrellj.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807110112/http://www.alamhof.org/darrellj.htm|url-status=dead|title=Alabama Music Hall of Fame: Johnny Darrell|archive-date=August 7, 2007|access-date=August 6, 2021}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" !
